acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity is not reported within the aqueous solubility concentrations (0.003mg/L (EU-RAR (2001))), it was classified into Not classified.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Classified using the data on rabbits, because no data on rats were available. Based on the LD50 value of 24,700mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (dermal route) of 24,500mg/kg (EU-RAR No.42 (2003)), 25,000mg/kg (EHC131 (1992)), and 24,750mg/kg, (ACGIH (7th, 2001).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 (mist) of over 10.62 mg/L (EU-RAR No.42 (2003)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of over 20,000, over 40,000mg/kg (EU-RAR No.42 (2003)); 30,600mg/kg (ATSDR (2002)), 33,800 mg/kg (ACGIH (7th, 2001)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category R by NTP (2005), Group B2 by EPA (2002), Category A3 by ACGIH (2001) and Category 2B by the Japan Society for Occupational Health, although classified as Group 3 by IARC.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: May cause long lasting harmful effects to aquatic life
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although it is water-insolubility and acute toxicity was not reported within the aqueous solubility concentrations,since the decomposition rate was not high (the half life is 50 days by bio-decomposition in the water (EU-RAR (2001))and there was the bio-accumulation (BCF=840 (EU-RAR (2001)), it was classified into Category 4.

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flash point is 215degC (open cup flash test) (ICSC, 2002)

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that admistration route was not proper in the tests where positive results were observed, and based on the negative data on other dominant lethal tests and micronucleus tests, though positive results were observed in multi-generation mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests), described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.7 (2004), ATSDR (2002).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures; the auto-ignition temperature is 350degC (ICSC, 2002)

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: May damage fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of effects on offspring at dosing levels not toxic to parent animals, described in U.S. NTP-CERHR, CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.7 (2004).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in ACGIH (7th, 2001), ATSDR (2002), EHC 131 (1992) and EU-RAR No.42 (2003): Phthalic acid, bis (2-ethylhecyl) is considered "non-irritating" or "mildly irritating" to the eyes, with the latter adopted for classification.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in ATSDR (2002) and EU-RAR No.42 (2003): Phthalic acid, bis (2-ethylhecyl) causes mild irritation, if any, to the skin; Four-hour application causes mild skin irritation.

skin_sensitizer.rationale: Based on the description in EU-RAR No.42 (2003) - Phthalic acid, bis (2-ethylhecyl) does not cause skin sensitization, according to the results of guinea pig skin sensitization tests (performed based on the Maximization and Buehler Methods).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (testis, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "vacuolation of Sertoli cells in the testes" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.7 (2004)), "hepatocyte enlargement, periportal fat deposition, lipid replete lysosome, glycogen depletion, changes in the bile duct structure, induction of peroxisomal enzyme and cytochrome P450 activities" (CERI Hazard Data 96-17 (1997)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
